title: Market power and innovation
text:
Productivity.

Productivity grows because firms invest in R&D.
R&D is focused on the development of higher quality products and better production methods.

Higher quality products and higher productivity can be thought of as one and the same.

The optimal level of R&D depends on profitability, so market power should allow more investment and therefore should raise growth?

title: Market power and innovation
text:
Growth through creative destruction

What is the Schumpeterian approach to modelling firm heterogeneity?

Innovating firms become market leaders, displacing others.
Innovation is a random process: no amount of investment guarantees success.
Large firms are firms with a history of successful innovation.

The modern growth theory for creative destruction (Aghion & Howitt 1992) builds on Schumpeter (1942).


What is the model environment?

There are many products in the economy, where each product is produced by only a single firm.

The firm that produces that product changes over time through innovation.
Each good is produced by only one firm, but firms can produce multiple goods.

This means that there is no such thing as firm level productivity.


Innovation can come from market entrants or from competitors.
Innovation means that the incumbent stops producing that good — creative destruction.
Products are imperfect substitutes meaning that the firm that produces them has market power.
The incentives for entrants and competitors to innovate rise with market power.
Model equations
Aggregate consumption is a combination of many goods:
\[
  C_t = \left[\int_0^1C_{ij}^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}}dj\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}
  \]
Firms produce each good with a simple production function and all output is consumed.
\[
  Y_{ijt} = A_{ijt}L_{ijt}\\ Y_{ijt} = C_{jt}
  \]
A firm \(i\) produces a unique product as a monopolist and sets price \(P_i\) which is a markup \(\mu\) over marginal cost:
\[
  \mu = \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}
  \]



How do we model innovation?
Innovation improves the productivity with which a random good is produced.

Let firm \(i\) innovate on a good that firm \(h\) used to produce:
\[
  A_{ijt} = (1+\lambda) A_{hjt-1}
  \]

We call \(\lambda\) the innovation step. A larger lambda means greater quality innovation.

If firm \(i\) is an entrant, it enters the economy.
If firm \(i\) is an incumbent, it expands its portfolio of products.
Firm \(h\) is the incumbent that shrinks or exits, depending on its size — creative destruction.
What is the rate of creative destruction?
The rate of creative destruction, \(\tau\), is the probability that a product is replaced.
\[
  \tau = e + x
  \]

\(e\) is creative destruction by entrants, and \(x\) is creative destruction by incumbents.




How can we get the growth rate in this economy?
Starting with the CES aggregator, we have consumption,
\[
C_t = \left[\int_0^1 C_{jt}^\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon} dj\right]^\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1} = \left[\int_0^1 (A_{ijt}L_{ijt})^\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon} dj\right]^\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}
\]
If we allow all firms to employ the same number of people (apparently this is an easy assumption to drop), we can simplify this to,
\[
C_t = L\left[\int_0^1 A_{ijt}^\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}dj\right]^\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}
\] \[
\implies \ln(C_t) = \ln (L)+ \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1} \ln \left[\int_0^1A_{ijt}^\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}dj\right]
\]
This gives us the growth rate of the economy as,
\[
g = \tau \times \lambda
\]

Derivation
\[
  \begin{split}
  \frac{\delta \ln (C_t)}{\delta t} &= \frac{\delta}{\delta t}\left(\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1} \ln \underbrace{\left[\int_0^1A_{ijt}^\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}dj\right]}_{A_t}\right)\\ &= \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}\frac1{A_t}\frac{\delta}{\delta t}\left[\int_0^1A_{ijt}^\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}dj\right]
  \end{split}
  \]
A fraction \(\tau\) of all products get a productivity improvement at each time \(t\). This means that \(1 - \tau\) products don’t have any change in productivity.
\[
  \frac{\delta \ln(C_t)}{\delta t}= \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}\frac1{A_t}\frac{\delta}{\delta t}\left[\int_0^\tau A_{ijt}^\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}dj\right]
  \]
For every product that experience a productivity increase, their productivity increases by \(\lambda\).
\[
  \begin{split}
  \frac{\delta \ln(C_t)}{\delta t}&= \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1}\frac{1}{A_t}\int_0^\tau\frac{\delta}{\delta t}A_{ijt}^\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon} dj\\
  &=\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1}\frac{1}{A_t}\int_0^\tau\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon} A_{ijt}^\frac{-1}{\epsilon} \times \frac{\delta A_{ijt}}{\delta t} dj\\
  &=\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1}\frac{1}{A_t}\int_0^\tau\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon} A_{ijt}^\frac{-1}{\epsilon} \times \red{\lambda A_{ijt}} dj \text { from } A_{ijt+1} = (1+\lambda )A_{ijt}
  \\&= \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}\frac{1}{A_t}\lambda\int_0^\tau  A_{ijt}^\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon} dj \\
  &= \lambda \left[\frac{1}{A_t}\int_0^\tau A_{ijt}^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}}dj\right] \text{ where } \left[\frac{1}{A_t}\int_0^\tau A_{ijt}^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}}dj\right] = \tau\\
  &= \tau \times \lambda
  \end{split}
  \]



What are the key takeaways?
The creative destruction model means that growth is disruptive.

The growth rate is proportional to the fraction of products that is replaced,
\[
  g = \tau \times \lambda
  \]
Replacements come from competitors \(x\) or new firms \(e\).
The replacement of a product is disruptive with old firms shrinking or exiting.
To measure creative destruction, we can use measures of employment disruption:

Percentage of firms that enter and exit (or size-weighted).
Reallocation rate (sum of job creation and destruction rates).

title: Market power and innovation
text:
Creative destruction and market power

How do incumbents innovate?
To improve a product, incumbents must invest in R&D.

To develop a better product with probability \(x_i\), they employ researchers,
\[
  \text{rd}_i = x_i^\psi\times \phi
  \]
where \(\psi> 1\) and \(\phi> 0\) and \(\text{rd}\) is the number of researchers hired.
Entrants are entrepreneurs who have to hire researchers too:
\[
  \text{rd}^e = e^\psi \times \phi^e
  \]
When producing a product, firms earn profits,
\[
  \pi_i = (p_i - \text{mc}_i) y_i
  \]

Where profits are increasing in markup.


What is the incumbent optimisation problem?
The incumbent wants to maximise the firm’s value by choosing the right level of innovation.

Firms discount the future at rate \(\rho\), and will still produce a given good at time \(t\) with probability \(1-\tau\).
\[
  V_i = \sum_{t=0}^\infty\left(\frac1{1+\rho}(1-\tau)\right)^t \pi_i
  \]
Using the formula for an infinite geometric series, we get,
\[
  V_i = \frac{\pi_i}{1-\frac{1-\tau}{1+\rho}}
  \]

The value of becoming a producer increases in profits and decreases in \(\tau\) and \(\rho\).

The firms maximisation problem is therefore,
\[
  \Pi_i = \max_{x_i}(x_iV_i - x_i^\psi\phi), \\\Pi^e = \max_{e}(eV_e - e^\psi\phi^e)
  \]

Firms are maximising the value from innovating, multiplied by the probability that it occurs, minus the cost of the R&D for the innovation.

Taking the first order conditions tells us that the optimal innovation rate and entry rate therefore increases in profits:
\[
  \left .\frac{\delta}{\delta x_i}\right|_{x_i^*}\left(x_i V_i - x_i^\psi\phi\right) = 0\\V_i - \psi x_i^{\psi - 1}\phi = 0 \implies
  x_i^* = \left(\frac{V_i}{\phi}\right)^{\frac{1}{\psi - 1}}
  \] \[
  \left .\frac{\delta}{\delta e}\right|_{e^*}\left(e V_e - e^\psi\phi^e\right) = 0\\V_e - \psi e^{\psi - 1}\phi^e = 0 \implies
  e^* = \left(\frac{V_e}{\phi^e}\right)^{\frac{1}{\psi - 1}}
  \]
What is the total innovation by incumbents and entrants then?
\[
  \tau = \int x_i di + e
  \]
where \(\tau\) is total innovation, given by the continuum of probabilities chosen by incumbents and the innovation by entrepreneurs.







Note



Given that growth increases in creative destruction \(\tau,\) that means that profits drive growth!
\[
\pi\uparrow \implies V_i = \frac{\pi_i}{1-\frac{1-\tau}{1+\rho}} \uparrow \implies x_i^* = \left(\frac{V_i}{\phi}\right)^{\frac{1}{\psi - 1}} \uparrow \implies \tau = \int x_i di + e\uparrow \implies g = \tau \times \lambda \uparrow
\]

title: Productivity dispersion, concentration, oligopoly
text:
Firm level datasets are based on accounting data.

Markups are the ratio of prices to marginal cost and accounting data does not contain either of them.

We don’t directly observe marginal cost or prices.

This means at the firm level we need an estimator to obtain markups.

At the aggregate level, we can infer markups from the labour share for example.








Tip



This means we need an estimator to obtain the markup.





The production function approach to markup estimation.
Assume that all firms have the following production function:
\[
Y_{it} = A_{it}K_{it}^{\alpha_k}L_{it}^{\alpha_l}M_{it}^{\alpha_m}
\]
For a given output level, the firm’s objective is to minimise their costs, subject to a given production level, by choosing their mix of factor inputs:
\[
\text{TC}_{it} = R_tK_{it} + W_tL_{it}+P_t^mM_{it}
\]
\[
\mathcal{L}=R_tK_{it} + W_tL_{it}+P_t^mM_{it} - \lambda_{it}[A_{it}K_{it}^{\alpha_k}L_{it}^{\alpha_l}M_{it}^{\alpha_m}-Y_{it}]
\]

\(\lambda_{it}\) is the marginal cost of production.

We assume that firms choose \(M_{it}\) each period without adjustment costs.

This is because it is easy for firms to adjust the amount of materials they purchase, but not easy to adjust labour or capital.
What is the optimisation?
\[
  \left.\frac{\delta\mathcal{L}}{\delta M_{it}}\right |_{M^*} = P_t^m - \lambda_{it}A_{it}K_{it}^{\alpha_k}L_{it}^{\alpha_l}m_{it}^{\alpha_m- 1}\alpha_m = 0\\
  \] \[
  P_t^m = \lambda_{it}\alpha_m\left(\frac{Y_{it}}{M_{it}}\right)\\
  \] \[
  \frac{P_{it}}{\lambda_{it}} = \alpha_m\left(\frac{P_{it}Y_{it}}{P_t^mM_{it}}\right) = \mu_{it}
  \]

\(P_{it}Y_{it}\) is total firm revenue and \(P_t^m M_{it}\) is total spending on goods from other firms.

These are both things that we can get from the income statement.

The only thing we don’t know is the output elasticity \(\alpha_m\).






What are the different stages?

Use revenue and costs data from accounting data.

Assume that cost of goods sold is chosen without adjustment costs.
Use sector deflated sales to measure output.

Estimate the production function of firms to obtain \(\alpha_m\).

Controlling for other inputs: capital, sales, general administrative expenses.

Assume firms within broad industries have the same \(\alpha_m\).

What is the estimation process?
Assume that the log of productivity is a linear first-order autoregressive process:
\[
  y_{it} = {a}_{it}+\alpha_k k_{it} + \alpha_l l_{it} + \alpha_m m_{it}
  \] \[
  a_{it} = \rho a_{it-1} + \eta_{it}
  \]

We can’t just run OLS on the first equation as we have correlation between the error term, which is productivity, and the regressors. This means we need an identification assumption.

Highly productive firms will naturally produce more and therefore use more inputs than low productivity firms.


The identification assumption is that firms don’t know \(\eta_{it}\) at time \(t-1\).

This means that \(k_{it-1}, l_{it-1}, m_{it-1}\) should be uncorrelated with \(\eta_{it}\), as firms don’t know yet what the shock to productivity is going to be.
How can we arrive at our estimates?

Guess values for \(\alpha_k, \alpha_l,\alpha_m\).
Calculate productivity using these guesses:
\[
a_{it} = y_{it} - \alpha_kk_{it} - \alpha_l l_{it} - \alpha_m m_{it}
\]
Regress \(a_{it} = \rho a_{it-1} + \eta_{it}\) to find \(\rho\) and \(\eta_{it}\).
Update the guesses until \(\eta_{it}\) is not correlated with \(k_{it-1}, l_{it-1}, m_{it-1}\).

title: Productivity dispersion, concentration, oligopoly
text:
Oligopoly: Atkeson and Burstein (2008)

How does the Atkeson and Burstein model alter the Dixit-Stiglitz model?
The Dixit-Stiglitz model focussed on product differentiation as the main source of market power. The Atkeson and Burstein model focusses on markets being sufficiently small for firms to interact strategically as the main source of market power.






Tip



Some firms compete very closely, for example, Itsu and Wasabi on High Holborn. Conversely, other firms don’t really compete at all, for example, Itsu in High Holborn, and the Ford dealership in Ashford.



There are many sectors in the economy (products, locations, etc).
It is very difficult to substitute goods across sectors.
Within sectors, a small number of closer substitute firms compete.
What are the consequences of these alterations?

Large firms will have less competition and therefore higher markups.
Markups increase convexly in market share.
Productivity dispersion causes an increase in average markup and markup dispersion.




What is the model environment?

Aggregate consumption \(C\) is a Dixit-Stiglitz basket of many sectors.
\[
  C = \left[\int_0^1 C_j^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} dj\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1}}
  \]
Demand for sector \(j\)’s output depends on the price index:
\[
  C_j = P_j^{-\epsilon}Y
  \]
A sector’s output is produced by \(N_j\) firms \(i\):
\[
  C_j = \left[\sum_{i=1}^{N_j}C_{ij}^{\frac{\sigma - 1}{\sigma}}dj\right]^{\frac{\sigma}{\sigma - 1}}
  \]







Tip



Key assumption is that \(\sigma > \epsilon\): meaning that goods are more similar within sectors than across sectors.




What is the household optimisation problem?
\[
\mathcal{L} = \sum_{i=1}^{N_j}(P_{ij} \times C_{ij}) - \lambda\left( \left[ \sum_{i = 1}^{N_j} C_{ij}^{\frac{\sigma - 1}{\sigma}} di\right]^{\frac{\sigma}{\sigma - 1}} - C_j\right)
\]
The first order condition with respect to \(C_i\) is,
\[
\begin{split}
\left.\frac{\delta\mathcal{L}}{\delta C_i}\right|_{C_i^*} &= P_{ij} - \lambda \frac{\sigma}{\sigma - 1} \left[ \sum_{i = 1}^{N_j} C_{ij}^{\frac{\sigma - 1}{\sigma}} di\right]^{\frac{\sigma}{\sigma - 1} -1} \frac{\sigma - 1}{\sigma} C_{ij}^{\frac{\sigma - 1}{\sigma} - 1} = 0\\
P_{ij} &= \lambda \left[ \sum_{i = 1}^{N_j} C_{ij}^{\frac{\sigma - 1}{\sigma}} di\right]^{\frac{1}{\sigma - 1}} C_{ij}^{-\frac{1}{\sigma}}\\
P_{ij}^{-\sigma} &=\lambda^{-\sigma}C_j^{-1}C_{ij}\\
C_{ij}&=\lambda^\sigma P_{ij}^{-\sigma}C_j
\end{split}
\]
To get rid of the Lagrange multiplier, we can use the relative demand between two goods:
\[
\frac{C_{ij}}{C_1} = \frac{\lambda^\sigma P_{ij}^{-\sigma}C_j}{\lambda^\sigma P_{1}^{-\sigma}C_j} \implies \frac{C_{ij}}{C_1} = \left(\frac{P_{ij}}{P_1}\right)^{-\sigma}
\]
Therefore the relative demand between two goods is determined by the price ratio and how similar they are.
Inserting this into the customers total spending on consumption baskets for that sector:
\[
\sum_{i=1}^{N_j}P_{ij}C_{ij}di = \sum_{i=1}^{N_j} P_{ij} C_1\left(\frac{P_{ij}}{P_1}\right)^{-\sigma}\\
\implies C_1 = P_1^{-\sigma}\left(
\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N_j} P_{ij}C_{ij}}{\sum_{i=1}^{N_j} P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}}
\right)
\]
Using the definition of the sector price index \(P_j\),
\[
P_j \equiv \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N_j} P_{ij}C_{ij}}{C_j}
\]


What is the firm optimisation problem?
Firms have constant marginal costs \(\text{MC}_{ij}\) such that profits are,
\[
\pi_{ij} = (P_{ij} - \text{MC}_{ij})C_{ij}
\]
Firms want to maximise their profits by setting their price. \(C_{ij}\) is a function of \(P_{ij}\).
\[
\begin{split}
\left .\frac{\delta \pi_{ij}}{\delta P_{ij}}\right|_{P_{ij}^*} &= C_{ij} + P_{ij} \frac{\delta C_{ij}}{\delta P_{ij}} - \text{MC}_{ij} \frac{\delta C_{ij}}{\delta P_{ij}} = 0 \text{ }\textcolor{red}{(\times P_{ij}, \div C_{ij})}\\
&\implies P_{ij} + P_{ij}\frac{P_{ij}}{C_{ij}}\frac{\delta C_{ij}}{\delta P_{ij}} - \text{MC}_{ij}\frac{P_{ij}}{C_{ij}}\frac{\delta C_{ij}}{\delta P_{ij}} = 0\\
&\implies P_{ij} = \text{MC}_{ij}\left(\frac{\frac{P_{ij}}{C_{ij}}\frac{\delta C_{ij}}{\delta P_{ij}}}{1+\frac{P_{ij}}{C_{ij}}\frac{\delta C_{ij}}{\delta P_{ij}}}\right) = \text{MC}_{ij} \left(\frac{-\varepsilon_{ij}}{1 - \varepsilon_{ij}}\right)
\end{split}
\]
This gives the famous oligopoly result,
\[
P_{ij} =\text{MC}_{ij}\left(\frac{\varepsilon_{ij}}{\varepsilon_{ij}-1}\right)
\]
\(-\varepsilon_{ij}\) is the price elasticity of demand.

What is the markup determined by in this model?
The markup \(\mu_{ij}\) is now determined by the price elasticity of demand.
\[
  \mu_{ij} = \left(\frac{\varepsilon_{ij}}{\varepsilon_{ij}-1}\right)
  \]

In last week’s model, the epsilon was constant, but here, the price elasticity of demand varies across firms.

Some firms will have a low PED and therefore a high markup meaning that it is hard for the household to substitute away from their goods, so firms can cahrge higher prices.

title: Productivity dispersion, concentration, oligopoly
text:
Concentration and Markup
To determine the markup, we have to know what the price elasticity of demand is.
\[
\mu_{ij} = \left(\frac{\varepsilon_{ij}}{\varepsilon_{ij}-1}\right)
\]

What determines the price elasticity of demand?
The main insights of the Atkeson and Burstein model are,

Larger firms have lower price elasticity of demand \(\varepsilon_{ij}\).

This is caused by the effect of a large firm’s price increases on the sector price index.
If a monopolist raises prices, households can only substitute away to other sectors.




How can we determine the markup?
Step 1 — Find firm demand as a function of prices.
The firm and sector demand functions are,
\[
C_{ij} = \left(\frac{P_{ij}}{P_j}\right)^{-\sigma}Y_j \text{ and }Y_j = P_j^{-\epsilon}C
\]

For example, the first function is the demand for Itsu sushi on High Holborn, while the second function is the total demand for sushi on High Holborn.

We can combine these two functions to get a demand function for ‘Itsu’ sushi (firm demand) in terms of total consumption \(C\) and the firm and sector prices.
\[
\begin{split}
C_{ij} &= \left(\frac{P_{ij}}{P_j}\right)^{-\sigma}P_j^{-\epsilon}C\\
C_{ij} &= P_{ij}^{-\sigma}P_j^{\sigma - \epsilon}C
\end{split}
\]
Step 2 — Take logs and derivatives to get price elasticity of demand.
In order to calculate the price elasticity, we need to take the \(\log\) of the function above and then take the derivative with respect to price.
\[
\ln C_{ij} = -\sigma\ln(P_{ij}) + (\sigma - \epsilon)\ln(P_j) + \ln (C)
\] \[
\frac{\delta \ln(C_{ij})}{\delta \ln(P_{ij})} = -\sigma + (\sigma - \epsilon)\frac{\delta \ln(P_j)}{\delta \ln(P_{ij})}
\]
Step 3 — Calculate \(\frac{\delta \ln(P_j)}{\delta \ln(P_{ij})}\).
Because there are only a few firms in each sector, the sector’s price index depends on \(P_{ij}\).
\[
P_j = \left[\sum_{i=1}^{N_j} P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}\right]^{\frac{1}{1-\sigma}}\\
\] \[
\ln P_j = \frac{1}{1-\sigma} \ln \left[\sum_{i=1}^{N_j} P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}\right]\\
\] \[
\begin{split}
\frac{\delta \ln(P_j)}{\delta \ln(P_{ij})} &= \left(\frac{1}{1-\sigma}\right)\frac{1}{\sum_{i=1}^{N_j} P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}} \frac{\delta P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}}{\delta \ln(P_{ij})}\\
&= \left(\frac{1}{1-\sigma}\right)\frac{1}{P_j^{1-\sigma}}P_{ij}^{-\sigma} (1-\sigma)P_{ij}\\
&= \frac{P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}}{P_j^{1-\sigma}}
\end{split}
\]

What two things does the second to last line use?
The first part comes from the price index equation:
\[
  P_j = \left[\sum_{i=1}^{N_j} P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}\right]^{\frac{1}{1-\sigma}} \implies \sum_{i=1}^{N_j} P_{ij}^{1-\sigma} = P_j^{1-\sigma}
  \]
The second part uses the a \(\log\) derivative rule:
\[
  \frac{\delta f(x)}{\delta \ln(x)} = \frac{\delta f(x)}{\delta x} \cdot x
  \]

Step 4 — Show that \(\frac{P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}}{P_j^{1-\sigma}}\) is equal to the firm’s market share.
\[
\text{Firm revenue} = P_{ij}C_{ij} = P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}P_j^{\sigma - \epsilon}C\\
\] \[
\text{Sector revenue} = P_jC_j = P_j^{1-\epsilon}C\\
\] \[
\text{Market share} = S_{ij} = \frac{P_{ij}C_{ij}}{P_jC_j} = \frac{P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}P_j^{\sigma - \epsilon}C}{P_j^{1-\epsilon}C} = \frac{P_{ij}^{1-\sigma}}{P_j^{1-\sigma}}
\]
We can insert this into the price elasticity equation,
\[
\frac{\delta \ln(C_{ij})}{\delta \ln(P_{ij})} = -\sigma + (\sigma - \epsilon)S_{ij}
\] \[
-\varepsilon_{ij} = -\sigma + (\sigma - \epsilon)S_{ij}
\] \[
\varepsilon_{ij} = \sigma(1-S_{ij}) + \epsilon S_{ij}
\]


What happens if you are an infinitesimal firm?
\[
S_ij \to 0 \implies \varepsilon_{ij} = \sigma(1-S_{ij}) + \epsilon S_{ij} \to \sigma
\] \[
\implies P_{ij} =\text{MC}_{ij} \left(\frac{\sigma}{\sigma - 1}\right)
\]

This shows that very small firms compete within their own sector.



What happens if you are a monopolist?
\[
S_{ij} \to 1 \implies \varepsilon_{ij} = \sigma(1-S_{ij}) + \epsilon S_{ij} \to \epsilon
\] \[
\implies P_{ij} = \text{MC}_{ij}\left(\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}\right)
\]

This shows that very large firms compete more across sectors.



How does the markup increase with market share?
A standard calibration of parameters sets \(\sigma = 10\) and \(\epsilon = 1.1\).


This shows markups increasing convexly with market share meaning that as market share approaches 100%, markups increase faster and faster.



Can the model explain the trends we see in the data?

The model can show a rise in markups over time.
The model can also show a rise in markup dispersion over time.
Finally, the model can explain that if productivity differences cause an increase in concentration, markups and markup dispersion increase endogenously.

title: Growing Differences Between Firms
text:
Heterogeneity in firm size.

Outputs: sale, value added, profits.
Inputs: labour, capital, intermediate inputs (goods produced by other firms).
Measures of size follow a Pareto distribution.

Lots of small firms, fewer medium ones, and even fewer large ones.


Heterogeneity in firm activity.

Operating in different sectors and locations.

Determines competitors, quality of labour inputs, infrastructure access, etc.


Heterogeneity in firm technology.

Some firms are more productive than others.

Management practices, vintage capital, past innovation.
Customer capital, bank relationships and equity/bond access.







Lucas/Hopenhayn/Melitz approach:

Firms have different idiosyncratic productivities.

Peculiar things they are good at.

More productive firms should be larger than unproductive firms.
May not be at optimal size due to frictions (e.g. financial) \(\rightarrow\) misallocation.

At 50 employees or more, French firms face a lot more regulation, and so there are very few firms with 50 employees.


Schumpeterian/Klette-Kortum approach:

Innovating firms become market leaders, displacing others (creative destruction).
Innovation is random process: no amount of investment guarantees success.
Large firm: firm with history of successful (lucky) innovation.





There are two main ingredients for heterogeneous firm \(i\) operating in sector \(j\).
\[
\begin{split}
Y_{ijt} &= \textcolor{red}{A_{ijt}} F_{jt}(K_{ijt}, L_{ijt},M_{ijt}) \\
Y_{ijt} &= \textcolor{red}{\Omega_{ijt}}\times P_{ijt}^{-\epsilon_{ijt}} \text{ where } P_{ijt} = MC_{ijt} \times \mu_{ijt}
\end{split}
\]

Production function with heterogeneity in productivity through \(A_{ijt}\).

Factors of production are \(K,L,M\) which are capital, labour and materials respectively.

The demand function depends on the demand shifter \(\Omega_{ijt}\) and the firm’s price \(P_{ijt}\).

Some firms, for a given price, may have higher demand for their goods than others (represented by \(\Omega\)). For a given amount of inputs, people are happier with the product that you offer. An example would be Apple MacBooks; on paper they may have the same specs as other high end computers, but they have a higher demand due to customer loyalty and the brand association.

Productive firms have lower marginal costs and a lower price, which leads to them producing more output.

However, there is some source of diminishing returns to scale, either through demand or supply.
Diminishing returns to scale are assumed because if it wasn’t there, the most productive firm would dominate the market, but in reality we don’t see that.

Demand: a love of variety means that consumers likely don’t want to consume just one thing.
Supply: \(F_{ijt}(\lambda K_{ijt}, \lambda L_{ijt}, \lambda M_{ijt}) < \lambda Y_{ijt}\).

Multiplying all inputs by \(\lambda\) increases the output by less than \(\lambda\).

title: Growing Differences Between Firms
text:
Firm heterogeneity in data

Where does heterogeneity data come from?

Most data on firm heterogeneity comes from accounting data:

Flow variables such as sales, wage bill, inputs, profits come from the income statement.
Stocks such as assets (for measuring capital) and debt come from the balance sheet.
This is complemented with other micro data.

Prices from surveys, scanner data and customs records.
Employment data from tax records or social security files.
Firm-to-firm transactions data from VAT registries.


Researchers can access this data in two ways:

Tax or census offices who make data available to accredited/sworn researchers.
Commercial providers who collect regulatory financial data submissions.




Analysis of stylised facts
Most economic activity comes from the largest firms.


92% of firms have less than 20 employees.
10% of firms are responsible for over 80% of employment.
92% of firms are responsible for only just over 11% of sales.

Firm size distribution is highly skewed and fat tailed.

What is the cumulative distribution function of a Pareto distribution? \[
  P(X<x) \equiv F(x) = 1- \left(\frac{x}{x_m}\right)^{-\alpha}
  \] where \(x_m\) is the scale parameter and \(\alpha\) is the shape parameter. \(\alpha\) determines how fat the tail of the distribution is.
What is the probability density function of a Pareto distribution? \[
  P(X=x) \equiv f(x) = \frac{\alpha}{x_m}\left(\frac{x}{x_m}\right)^{-\alpha - 1}
  \] The PDF is a log-linear function meaning that if we apply a log transformation to it, it becomes a linear function.
\[
  \begin{split}
  \log(f(x)) &= \log(\alpha) - \log(x_m) + (-\alpha - 1)(\log(x) - \log(x_m))\\
  &= \log(\alpha) + \alpha \log(x_m) -(1+\alpha)\log(x)\\
  &=\phi - (1+\alpha)\log(x) \text{ where } \phi = \log(\alpha) + \alpha \log(x_m)
  \end{split}
  \]
This means that we easily estimate the parameters of our distribution using OLS.

Estimating firm size distribution


Here we are regressing the log of what fraction of firms have a given number of employees on the log of the number of employees. If it is a clear linear fit, then the distribution is Pareto.
Why is it important that the distribution of firm size is fat tailed?

Fat tail means large firms are much more common than with a normal distribution.
These firms can have non-negligible effects on macroeconomy.

Large firms have market power and can extract profits.
Large firms may also be responsible for some business cycles.

Extreme example: in 2000, Nokia caused Finnish GDP to grow by 1.6%.



Productivity is highly dispersed even among firms in narrow industries.

Productivity heterogeneity is a potential driver of firm heterogeneity: \[
  Y_{ijt} = \textcolor{red}{A_{ijt}} \times F(K_{ijt}, L_{ijt},M_{ijt})
  \]
This is because more productive firms can produce higher output for the same amount of inputs.

Lower marginal costs \(\rightarrow\) lower prices \(\rightarrow\) more demand and more inputs.
This means we would expect more productive firms to be larger.

As firm size is so dispersed, we would therefore expect that productivity across those firms is also very dispersed.
How can we measure productivity? To measure productivity, we have to assume a production function, in this case, cobb-douglas: \[
  y_{ijt} = a_{ijt} + \alpha^K k_{ijt} + \alpha^Ll_{ijt} + \alpha^Mm_{ijt}
  \]
However, we can’t just use OLS on this as the residual is productivity which would created omitted variable bias from being correlated with \(k,l,\) and \(m\). We instead have to use an instrumental variables approach.
Productivity dispersion in data 
This graph shows the yearly deviation from average TFP for both low density markets and high density markets.

Firms at the 85th percentile of productivity tend to be 2 to 4 times more productive than those at the 15th percentile.
This dispersion of productivity can even be seen in narrow industries (in the US).

title: Growing Differences Between Firms
text:
Recent trends in firm heterogeneity

What trends can we see in the last 20 years of data on firm heterogeneity?

Size (as measured through employment or sales) — there has been an increase in product-market concentration, ie, largest firms are getting larger.
Productivity — overall productivity growth has slowed down, but the largest firms productivity growth has remained high.
Profitability and market power — average markup of prices over marginal costs has increased. This has been driven by increases in markups at the highest percentiles of the distribution and coincides with a decline in the labour share of national income.



What are two measures of market concentration?

Traditional measure: Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI).
\[
\text{HHI}_{jt} = \sum_{i \in I_j} \left(\frac{py_{ijt}}{PY_{jt}}\right)^2
\]

\(0\) under perfect competition, \(1\) in monopoly and convex in between.
Often used in antitrust guidelines (\(0.18\) FTC threshold in the US).
The downside is that it requires data from all firms which may not be readily available.

New common measure: Concentration Ratio.
\[
\text{CR}_{jt}^X = \sum_{i=1}^X\left(\frac{py_{ijt}}{PY_{jt}}\right)
\]

Share of largest \(X\) firms in the industry.
Only requires data on the largest firms and the sector’s output.




How has market concentration changed?




Overall market concentration has increased but sales concentration rose faster than employment concentration.

Sales, \(P_{ijt}\times Y_{ijt}\), can increase because of changes in output OR prices.
\[
  \begin{split}
  Y_{ijt} &= \textcolor{red}{A_{ijt}}\times F(K_{ijt},L_{ijt}, M_{ijt}) \\
  P_{ijt} &= \text{MC}_{ijt} \times \textcolor{red}{\mu_{ijt}}
  \end{split}
  \]

Firms might have an increase in sales due to being more productive, but it could also be due to them charging higher prices and having a greater markup (\(\mu_{ijt}\)) on their marginal costs (\(\text{MC}_{ijt}\)).
\(A_{ijt}\) represents the firm’s technology which affects how efficiently they can produce.
\(\mu_{ijt}\) represents their market power — firms with lots of market power can have higher markups on their marginal costs.




How has productivity changed?



In the US, productivity growth has slowed since the early 2000s.
In France, productivity has actually been trending downwards since the 2000s.



The productivity of initially more productive firms in 2000 has increased since 2000 while the least productive firms have seen no real change in productivity.
This could be one explanation for the increase in industry concentration.



How can we measure market power?
\[
\mu_{ijt} = \frac{P_{ijt}}{\text{MC}_{ijt}}
\]
The markup of price over marginal cost is the purest measure of market power.

In a perfectly competitive market, the markup should be \(1\).
A markup of more than \(1\), indicates that the firm has some market power.

In practice, the markup is often greater than \(1\) because firms have fixed costs to cover or R&D expenses to recuperate.
However, it can also be due to having greater market power through high barriers to entry for example.




How have markups changed?



Average markup of US listed firms.





Average markup by percentile.



Average markups have increased a lot since the 1980s from just over 1 in 1980 to over 1.5 since 2010.
There has also been a large increase in markup dispersion since the 1980s, with the largest firms increasing their markup by a significant amount while the smaller firms have kept their markup broadly the same.

This suggests the increase in average markup is driven by an increase in markups of the largest firms.




How has the labour share of national income changed?


Despite firms charging a lot more money for their products, the share of national income that is paid in wages to workers has decreased significantly since the early 2000s.

Gross profits: total revenues minus cost of goods sold.
Operating profits: gross profits minus general and administrative expenses.
Net income: operating profits minus interest expenses and taxes.

The net income of a firm that owns its own capital:
\[
\pi_{it} = PY_{it} - W_tL_{it}- P_t^mM_{it}
\]



Economic profit is the difference between revenue and fair factor payments.

At the firm level:
\[
  \pi_{it} = PY_{it}- W_tL_{it}- r_tP_t^kK_{it} - P_t^mM_{it}
  \]

If a firm owns its own capital, it is forgoing the rent on that capital.
\(r_tP_t^kK_{it}\) is the rental rate of capital, multiplied by the price of capital and the quantity of capital.

At the macro level (closed or balanced trade economy):
\[
  \pi_t = PY_t - W_tL_t - r_tP_t^kK_t
  \]

For a closed economy the last term disappears. This is because this represents payments to other firms for materials and so when we add them all up, these terms cancel out.

Barkai (2000) shows that these economic profits as a share of GDP are increasing.




\[
\pi_t = PY_t - W_tL_t - r_tP_t^kK_t
\]

To measure profits, we need data on production, labour income and capital income.

Production: nominal gross value added (national accounts \(\approx\) GDP).
Labour income: total compensation of employees (national accounts).
For fair capital payments, we need capital stock, rental rate and the price of capital.

Capital stock: fixed assets from national capital data (excluding housing).
Price of capital: based on investment price index.
Rate of return: cost of corporate bonds/commercial paper borrowing.

Risk adjustment: owning capital depreciates and is risky so it requires compensation.
Derive the capital risk premium from the equity risk premium.










The first graph shows the return on equity and debt over time (along with the WACC) which has been steadily declining over the last 40 years.

Investors have demanded a lower and lower rate of return since the 80s, this is represented in a declining real interest rate.

Depreciation and expected inflation has remained broadly constant.
The required rate of return, \(r_t\) in the formula, has steadily been falling.
We see from the last two graphs that the capital share of GDP has been steadily declining while the pure profit share of GDP has been increasing.

As we saw last week, the labour share of national income has also been declining which contradicts the premise with a cobb-douglas production function that if the capital share decreases, the labour share must increase.

title: Firm Heterogeneity and Market Power
text:
Market power through monopolies

What are the main sources of pure economic profits in the macroeconomy?

Markets can be sufficiently small for firms to interact strategically.

For example through barriers to entry (fixed costs, regulation).
Or market size, for example, convenience shops.

Firms may have technological advantages

Could be the result of innovation.

Firms can differentiate the product that they offer.

This is the most common source of market power in macroeconomic models (BoE, Fed, ECB).


Dixit-Stiglitz Constant Elasticity of Substitution Aggregator

Source of market power comes from product differentiation and monopoly.
There is heterogeneity in productivity (and thus size) and activity.
What are the ingredients of this model?

Consumers have a love of variety which means they want to consume a basket of goods.
Firms produce with a simple production function:
\[
  Y_i = A_iL_i
  \]

The only factors are productivity and labour.

Firms charge a price that’s a markup \(\mu_i\) over marginal costs:
\[
  P_i = \mu_i\text{MC}_i \implies P_i = \mu_i\left(\frac{W}{A_i}\right)
  \]

The marginal cost of producing a good is the wage divided by their productivity, ie, how much it costs to hire an additional person divided by how much that person can produce.





How do we define aggregate consumption \(C\)?
Aggregate consumption is a combination (basket) of many goods:
\[
C = \left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}
\]

A firm \(i\) produces a unique product as a monopolist and sets price \(P_i\).
There is a continuum of goods with a measure of 1.

This is an approximation because there are thousands of coffee shops and supermarkets etc.

The elasticity of substitution \(\epsilon\) measures how similar products are and captures preferences.

As \(\epsilon \to \infty\), we get perfect competition as the more similar different goods are.
As \(\epsilon \to 1\), the more difficult it is for consumers to substitute away from other goods.

We get diminishing marginal utility from raising \(C_i\) to the power of \(\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon} < 1\). This means that holding everything else constant, increasing the consumption of one good, does not increase utility one for one. This captures the love of variety.
Conversely, we do have constant returns to scale. This comes from raising the integral to the power of \(\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}\). This means that increasing how much of everything we consume, increases utility by the same amount.

\[
\begin{split}
\left[\int_0^1 (\lambda C_i)^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}} &= \left[\lambda^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}}\int_0^1 C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}\\ &= \lambda^{(\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon} \times \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1})} \left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}\\ &= \lambda \left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}\\ &= \lambda C
\end{split}
\]

All output is consumed: \(Y_i = C_i\).

This is because there is no investment in this model.




What is the household problem?
The household, beyond deciding how much to work, must decide how much of each good to purchase, which they do by minimising their total spending:
\[
P \times C = \int^1_0 P_i \times C_i di
\]
Subject to the constraint:
\[
C = \left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}}di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}
\]
What is the Lagrangean for this problem?
\[
\mathcal{L} = \left[\int^1_0 P_i \times C_i di\right] - \lambda \left(\left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}}di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}-C\right)
\]

Even though every single product is unique, we only have to solve this for one good as the optimisation problem is the same across goods.
Households take the price of goods as given.



How do we solve the optimisation problem?
\[
\mathcal{L} = \left[\int^1_0 P_i \times C_i di\right] - \lambda \left(\left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}}di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}-C\right)
\]
First order condition with respect to \(C_i\):
\[
\begin{split}
\left.\frac{\delta\mathcal{L}}{\delta C_i}\right|_{C_i^*} &= P_i - \lambda\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1}\left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}}di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1} - 1}\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}-1}= 0\\
P_i &= \lambda\overbrace{\left(\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1}\times\frac{\epsilon -1}{\epsilon}\right)}^{=1}C_i^{\overbrace{\frac{\epsilon-1}{\epsilon} - 1}^{=-1/\epsilon}}\left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}}di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}-1}\\
P_i^{-\epsilon} &= \lambda ^{-\epsilon}C_i\left[\int^1_0C_i^{\frac{\epsilon-1}{\epsilon}}di\right]^{-\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}\\
P_i^{-\epsilon} &= \lambda^{-\epsilon}C_iC^{-1} \text{ where } C = \left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}}di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}} \\
C_i &=\lambda^{\epsilon}P_i^{-\epsilon}C
\end{split}
\]

This is saying how much of good \(i\) the household consumes depends inversely on the price of good \(i\) and how many baskets are consumed, \(C\).

The more baskets are consumed, the more of good \(i\) is consumed, but the higher the price of good \(i\), the lower the consumption of it is.


To get rid of the Lagrange multiplier, \(\lambda\), we use the relative demand between any two goods:
\[
\frac{C_i}{C_1} = \frac{\lambda^\epsilon P_i^{-\epsilon}C}{\lambda^\epsilon P_1^{-\epsilon}C} \implies \frac{C_i}{C_1} = \left(\frac{P_i}{P_1}\right)^{-\epsilon}
\]
We can now insert this result the household’s total spending on consumption goods, \(\int^1_0 P_i \times C_i di\):
\[
\begin{split}
\int^1_0 P_iC_i di &= \int_0^1P_iC_1\left(\frac{P_i}{P_1}\right)^{-\epsilon}di\\
\int^1_0 P_iC_i di &= C_1P_1^\epsilon \int_0^1P_i^{1-\epsilon}di\\
C_1 &= P_1^{-\epsilon}\left(\frac{\int_0^1 P_iC_idi}{\int_0^1 P_i^{1-\epsilon}di}\right)
\end{split}
\]

This equation tells us that the demand of good 1 is a function of the price of good 1.
The second part of the equation has total spending on top which means that the more is spent in total, the more good 1 is consumed. The bottom part is a measure of overall prices in the economy. The more expensive things are in the economy, for a given price of good 1, the more of it is consumed.

The definition of the price index \(P\) is:
\[
P_t \equiv \frac{\int_0^1 P_iC_idi}{C}
\]
To find the price index, we can insert the demand for individual goods \(i\):
\[
\begin{split}
P &= \frac{\int_0^1 P_iC_idi}{\left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}}\\
&= \frac{\int_0^1 P_i\left(\frac{P_i^{-\epsilon}\int_0^1 P_iC_idi}{\int_0^1 P_i^{1-\epsilon}di}\right)di}{\left[ \int_0^1 \left(\frac{P_i^{-\epsilon}\int_0^1 P_iC_idi}{\int_0^1 P_i^{1-\epsilon}di}\right)^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di \right]^\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1}} \\
&= \frac{X\int_0^1P_i \times P_i^{-\epsilon} di}{X^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon }\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}\left[\int_0^1 P_i^{1-\epsilon}\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}} \text{ where } X\equiv \frac{\int_0^1 P_iC_idi}{\int_0^1 P_i^{1-\epsilon}di}\\
&= \frac{\int_0^1 P_i^{1-\epsilon} di}{\left[ \int_0^1 P_i^{1-\epsilon} di \right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}}\\
&= \left[ \int_0^1P_i^{1-\epsilon} di \right]^{\frac{1}{1-\epsilon}}
\end{split}
\]
We can insert this back into the demand function to get the final demand function in terms of the price of an individual good compared to everything else:
\[
\begin{split}
C_1 &= P_1^{-\epsilon}\left(\frac{\int_0^1 P_iC_idi}{\int_0^1 P_i^{1-\epsilon}di}\right)\\
C_1 &= P_1^{-\epsilon} CP \frac{1}{P^{1-\epsilon}}\\
C_1 &= \left(\frac{P_1}{P}\right)^{-\epsilon}C
\end{split}
\]
Finally, we can insert the fact that the price \(P_1\) is equivalent to the marginal cost of production multiplied by a markup \(\mu_1\).
\[
Y_1 = C_1 = \left(\frac{W}{A_1}\times\frac{\mu_1}{P}\right)^{-\epsilon}C
\]

If a firm’s productivity increases, it will produce more.
If a firm’s markup increases, it will produce less.
The effect of productivity or markup increases with the elasticity of substitution.

title: Firm Heterogeneity and Market Power
text:
Macroeconomic effects of market power

What is the link between markup and wages?
Starting from the consumption basket, we can insert the demand function:
\[
C = \left[\int_0^1C_i^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}} = \left[\int_0^1\left(\left(\frac{W}{A_i}\times\frac{\mu_i}{P}\right)^{-\epsilon}C\right)^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}\\
\]
\[
\begin{split}
C &= \left[\int_0^1\left(\left(\frac{W}{A_i}\times\frac{\mu_i}{P}\right)^{-\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}} C^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon} \times \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}\\
1 &=\left[\int_0^1\left(\left(\frac{W}{A_i}\times\frac{\mu_i}{P}\right)^{-\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{\epsilon - 1}{\epsilon}} di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}\\
1 &= \left(\frac{W}{P}\right)^{-\epsilon}\left[\int_0^1\left(\frac{A_i}{\mu_i}\right)^{\epsilon - 1}di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}\\
\left(\frac{W}{P}\right)^{\epsilon} &= \left[\int_0^1\left(\frac{A_i}{\mu_i}\right)^{\epsilon - 1}di\right]^{\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon - 1}}\\
\frac{W}{P} &= \left[\int_0^1\left(\frac{A_i}{\mu_i}\right)^{\epsilon - 1}di\right]^{\frac{1}{\epsilon - 1}}
\end{split}
\]

The real wage increases with how productive firms are.

If we say that all firms have the same markup, \(\mu_i = \mu\), we get:
\[
\frac{W}{P} = \frac{1}{\mu}\left[\int_0^1(A_i)^{\epsilon - 1} di\right]^{\frac{1}{\epsilon - 1}}
\]

This means the real wage is a function of average productivity divided by the markup. Meaning that higher markups cause a markdown of wages.
This is because higher markups reduce the demand for goods, which reduces the demand for labour, which reduces the equilibrium wage.



What is the link between markup and output?
For now, assume that there is a constant labour supply \(L^s\), such that labour market equilibrium gives:
\[
L^s = \int_0^1 L_idi \implies L_s = \int_0^1Y_i/A_i di \text{ where } Y_i = A_iL_i
\]
Substituting in the demand function \((Y_i = C_i)\):
\[
L^s = \int_0^1 \textcolor{red}{\left(\frac{W}{A_i} \times\frac{\mu_i}{P}\right)^{-\epsilon}}\frac{\textcolor{red}{C}}{A_i}di
\]
Inserting the real wage:
\[
\begin{split}
L^s &= \int_0^1 \left(\frac{W}{A_i} \times\frac{\mu_i}{P}\right)^{-\epsilon}\frac{C}{A_i}di\\
L^s &= C\int_0^1 \left( \left[\int_0^1\left(\frac{A_i}{\mu_i}\right)^{\epsilon - 1}di\right]^{\frac{1}{\epsilon - 1}} \frac{\mu_i}{A_i}\right)^{-\epsilon} \frac{1}{A_i} di
\end{split}
\]
Let \(\mu_i = \mu\):
\[
\begin{split}
L^s &= C\int_0^1 \left( \overbrace{\left[\int_0^1\left({A_i}\right)^{\epsilon - 1}di\right]^{\frac{1}{\epsilon - 1}}}^{=A} \frac{1}{A_i}\right)^{-\epsilon} \frac{1}{A_i} di\\
\frac{L^s}{C}&= \int_0^1\left(A\times \frac{1}{A_i}\right)^{-\epsilon}\frac{1}{A_i} di\\
& = A^{-\epsilon}\int_0^1A_i^{\epsilon -1}di\\
&= A^{-\epsilon}\left(\left[\int_0^1A_i^{\epsilon -1}di\right]^\frac{1}{\epsilon - 1}\right)^{\epsilon - 1}\\
&= A^{-\epsilon} A^{\epsilon - 1}\\
&=A^{-1}\\
C &= L^s\left[\int_0^1 (A_i)^{\epsilon -1} di\right]^{\frac{1}{\epsilon - 1}}
\end{split}
\]

This tells us that, when markups are constant, there is no direct effect of the markup on output.



What is the link between markup and the labour share?
To get the labour share of output, we divide the real (nominal) wage payments by real (nominal) GDP:
\[
\frac{WL^s}{Y} = \frac{L^s\frac{1}{\mu} \left[ \int_0^1 A_i^{\epsilon -1}di\right]^\frac{1}{\epsilon - 1}}{L^s\left[ \int_0^1 A_i^{\epsilon -1}di\right]^\frac{1}{\epsilon - 1}} = \frac{1}{\mu}
\]

Intuitively, markups cause a part of income to go to profits and less to the factors of production.
The mechanism for this is that higher markups reduce labour demand, and therefore for the labour market to clear, the wage has to be lower.
Formally, markups cause a wedge between wage and marginal product.
This generalises to the other factors of production too: higher markups reduce the interest rate on capital.

title: Firm Heterogeneity and Market Power
text:
Concentration, productivity and markup dispersion

How do firms choose their markup?
So far, we have taken markups as exogenous, but there must be some profit maximising markup that firms would want to choose.

Assume there are no fixed costs, meaning that the firm’s objective function is,
\[
  \pi_i = (P_i - \text{MC}_i)C_i
  \]
The constraint is the demand function:
\[
  C_i = \left(\frac{P_i}{P}\right)^{-\epsilon}C
  \]
What is the solution to the optimisation problem?
\[
  \frac{\delta}{\delta P_i}(P_i - \text{MC}_i)\left(\frac{P_i}{P}\right)^{-\epsilon}Y = (1-\epsilon)Y\frac{P_i^{-\epsilon}}{P^{-\epsilon}} + \epsilon \frac{\text{MC}_i Y}{P^{-\epsilon}}P_i^{-\epsilon -1}
  \] \[
  \begin{split}
  0 &= (1-\epsilon)Y\frac{P_i^{-\epsilon}}{P^{-\epsilon}} + \epsilon \frac{\text{MC}_i Y}{P^{-\epsilon}}P_i^{-\epsilon -1}\\
  (\epsilon - 1) P_i^{-\epsilon}&= \epsilon \text{MC}_iP_i^{-\epsilon -1}\\
  \epsilon -1 &= \epsilon \text{MC}_iP_i^{-1}\\
  P_i &= \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1}\text{MC}_i
  \end{split}
  \]

This gives a famous result that the optimal price is a constant markup over marginal costs.
The markup comes from the market power that product differentiation yields.

As \(\epsilon \to \infty\), the markup goes to 1 and as \(\epsilon \to 1\), the markup goes to infinity.

This means that all firms in the economy charge the same markup, therefore this model cannot speak for why we have seen more and more markup dispersion over time.




Can the model explain the increase in market concentration?
High productivity means that a firm has low marginal costs.

If firms have low marginal costs, they are going to have low prices in this model.

To calculate concentration, we need to look at the relative demand between goods.
\[
\frac{C_1}{C_2} = \left(\frac{P_1}{P_2}\right)^{-\epsilon} \text{ and } P_i = \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon -1} \text{MC}_i
\]
Note that \(-\epsilon = -\frac{\mu}{\mu-1}\).
The relative demand for two firms is:
\[
\frac{C_1}{C_2} = \left(\frac{\text{MC}_1}{\text{MC}_2}\right)^{-\frac{\mu}{\mu -1}}
\]

A rise in productivity difference does cause a rise in concentration.
However, a rise in markups reduces concentration for given productivities.

title: Large firms, production networks, business cycles
text:
Lucas diversification argument (1977)

What is the Lucas diversification argument?
The Lucas diversification argument posits that micro shocks cannot affect the macroeconomy because they end up all cancelling out with each other.


What is the model environment?

The economy is composed of \(K\) production entities.

Could be firms, sectors, regions, … — something that is at the sub-aggregate level.

Factors are supplied inelastically, which means that only productivity shocks can affect the economy.
Entity \(k \in K\) is subject to idiosyncratic and i.i.d. output \(a_{k,t}\).
GDP is found by summing the output of all firms.
\[
  Y_t = \sum_{k\in K} a_{k,t}
  \]
We abstract from elastically supplied inputs and nominal rigidities, etc.



What is the GDP volatility in this economy?
Let the idiosyncratic shocks be as follows:
\[
\frac{\Delta a_{k,t}}{a_{k,t-1}} = \frac{a_{k,t} - a_{k,t-1}}{a_{k,t-1}} = \sigma_{k}\epsilon_{k,t}
\]

Where \(\epsilon_{k,t}\) has mean \(0\) and variance \(1\).

\(\sigma_k\) measures the size of the shock and represents the overall standard deviation of firm growth.


GDP growth is:
\[
\frac{\Delta Y_t}{Y_{t-1}} = \frac{1}{Y_{t-1}}\sum_{k\in K}\Delta a_{k,t} = \sum_{k \in K}\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}} \sigma_k \epsilon_{k,t}
\]

What is the standard deviation of GDP growth?
Shocks are independent and uncorrelated so \(\sigma_Y = \sqrt{\text{var}(\frac{\Delta Y_t}{Y_{t-1}})}\) is,
\[
  \sigma_Y = \left(\sum_{k \in K}\sigma_k^2\left[\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}}\right]^2\right)^{\frac12}
  \]

Mathematical derivation
We use the formula for calculating the variance,
\[
  \text{var}(X) = \mathbb{E}[X^2] - \mathbb{E}[X]^2
  \]
We will also use the fact that \(\epsilon_{k,t}\) has mean \(0\) and variance \(1\).
\[
  \begin{split}
  \mathbb{E}\left[\left( \sum_{k \in K}\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}} \sigma_k \epsilon_{k,t} \right)^2\right] - \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{k \in K}\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}} \sigma_k \epsilon_{k,t}\right]^2
  \end{split}
  \]
Because \(\epsilon_{k,t}\) has mean \(0\), the right hand side goes to \(0\). The next stage is to expand the square on the left hand side, which we do using the following formula:
\[
  \left(\sum_{k=1}^N x_k\right)^2 = \sum_{k=1}^N x_k \times \sum_{j=1}^N x_j = \sum_{k=1}^N \sum_{j=1}^N x_k  x_j
  \]
When we apply this to the expression inside the expectation term, we get,
\[
  \left( \sum_{k \in K}\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}} \sigma_k \epsilon_{k,t} \right)^2 =  \sum_{j \in J}\sum_{k \in K}\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}} \sigma_k \epsilon_{k,t} \frac{a_{j,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}} \sigma_j \epsilon_{j,t}
  \]
Using the fact that \(\epsilon_{k,t}\) has mean zero, along with the fact that \(\mathbb{E}[X+Y] = \mathbb{E}[X] + \mathbb{E}[Y]\), we can therefore reduce the left hand side of this whole expression to,
\[
  \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{k\in K} \sigma_k^2\epsilon_{k,t}^2\left[\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}}\right]^2\right]
  \]
This is because all of the terms where \(k \neq j\), take the expectation of different \(\epsilon_{k,t}\) meaning that the overall expectation of those terms is \(0\), leaving only the terms were \(k = j\).
We now use two more rules of expectations which are that the expectation of a constant is the constant, \(\mathbb{E}[\lambda] = \lambda\), and that the expectation of a product is equal to the product of expectations, \(\mathbb{E}[XY] = \mathbb{E}[X]\mathbb{E}[Y]\).
\[
  \begin{split}
  \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{k\in K} \sigma_k^2\left[\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}}\right]^2\right]\mathbb{E}[\epsilon_{k,t}^2] &= \left[\sum_{k\in K} \sigma_k^2\left[\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}}\right]^2\right](\mathbb{E}[\epsilon_{k,t}^2] + \mathbb{E}[\epsilon_{k,t}]^2)\\
  &= \left[\sum_{k\in K} \sigma_k^2\left[\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}}\right]^2\right]\text{var}(\epsilon_{k,t})
  \\
  &=\sum_{k\in K} \sigma_k^2\left[\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}}\right]^2
  \end{split}
  \]
This once again uses the fact that \(\mathbb{E}[\epsilon_{k,t}] = 0\) and therefore adds \(0\) to the term \(\mathbb{E}[\epsilon_{k,t}^2]\) and allows us to use the formula for the variance. This is useful because we know that the variance of \(\epsilon_{k,t}\) is \(1\). All that is left therefore is to take the square root to arrive at the standard deviation for GDP growth.
\[
  \sigma_Y = \left(\sum_{k \in K}\sigma_k^2\left[\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}}\right]^2\right)^{\frac12}
  \]








Critical assumption



Assume that all firms/production entities have the same volatility and size.


This reduces the volatility of GDP growth to,
\[
\begin{split}
\sigma_Y &= \left(\sum_{k \in K}\sigma_k^2\left[\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}}\right]^2\right)^{\frac12}\\
&= \left(\sum_{k \in K}\sigma_k^2\left[\frac{1}{N}\right]^2\right)^{\frac12}\\
&= \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{N}} \text{ where } N = |K|
\end{split}
\]

Empirically, \(N\) is large, so the effect of idiosyncratic shocks is very small.

Individual shocks average out to \(0\).
For example, across 473 NAICS manufacturing industries, the average volatility is 9% \((\sigma = 0.09)\).
\[
  \hat{\sigma}_Y = \frac{0.009}{\sqrt{473}} = 0.0041
  \]

This means that according to this model, idiosyncratic shocks cause a volatility of 0.41% while in reality, the GDP volatility of the manufacturing industry is 3%.

title: Large firms, production networks, business cycles
text:
Granular shocks
In most economic models, microeconomic shocks have no aggregate effects, this is because:

They assume a very large number of identical and small firms.
Idiosyncratic shocks cancel out by the law of large numbers.

In practice though, some firms are very large: e.g. Nokia in 2003 made up 26% of Finnish private sector GDP.

What is the effect of heterogeneous firm size on the diversification result?
If we allow for differences in firm size, but enforce the same volatility, we find that GDP volatility is the firm volatility multiplied by the square root of the Herfindahl (HHI) Index.
\[
\begin{split}
\sigma_Y &= \left(\sum_{k \in K}\sigma_k^2\left[\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}}\right]^2\right)^{\frac12}\\
&= \sigma \left(\sum_{k \in K}\left[\frac{a_{k,t-1}}{Y_{t-1}}\right]^2\right)^{\frac12}\\
&= \sigma h \text{ where $h$ is $\sqrt{\text{HHI}}$}
\end{split}
\]
Gabaix (2011) found that the Herfindahl declines slowly in \(N\) if firm size distribution is fat tailed.
In the data


Multiplying the HHI by an average firm volatility of 12% from Axtell (2001) gives a GDP volatility of about 1%.

title: Large firms, production networks, business cycles
text:
Hulten’s theorem

What is GDP?
So far, we have defined GDP as the sum of i.i.d. outputs \(a\). This is because in macroeconomics, we typically think of an aggregate production function \(Y = AF(K,L)\). However, at the micro level, there are many ‘production recipes’:
\[
Y_i = A_i F(K_i, L_i, \textcolor{red}{M_i})
\]
where \(M_i\) represents intermediate inputs. These intermediate inputs introduce a source of shock propagation for micro shocks to affect the macro economy.


What is Hulten’s Theorem (1978)?
Consider an efficient economy, meaning that welfare theorems apply. Then, under minimal assumptions, the following holds:
\[
\frac{d \log(Y)}{d \log(z_i)} = \lambda_i
\]
Here, \(\lambda_i\) is a firm or sector’s Domar weight:
\[
\lambda_i = \frac{p_iy_i}{\text{GDP}}
\]






Domar weights



The sum of all Domar weights should be greater than one because GDP represents value added, but firms use a lot of intermediate goods in their production, i.e., firm output is not the same as firm value added.




What is the derivation for Hulten’s theorem?
What is the model environment

The economy consists of \(n\) competitive firms/industries.
Each industry produces using,

\(n\) intermediate inputs.
\(m\) primary factors.

The production function has constant returns to scale and can be made up of any combination of inputs.
\[
  y_i = z_if(x_{i1},...,x_{in};I_{i1},..., I_{im})
  \]
A representative household has preferences over all goods.
\[
  Y = u(c_1,...,c_n)
  \]

This is also homogeneous of degree 1, meaning that multiplying all inputs by a constant, has the effect of multiplying the output by the same constant.

Of a firms output \(y_i\), \(c_i\) of it is consumed as final goods, and \(x_i\) is used as intermediate goods.
Households are endowed with \(h_k\) units of primary good \(k\).

As the welfare theorems hold, we can analyse this from the social planner’s perspective in order to simplify the problem.
What is the social planner’s problem?
The social planner chooses consumption, factor, and intermediate usage to maximise utility.
\[
Y = \max_{c_i, I_{ik}, x_{ij}} u(c_1,...,c_n) \text{ s.t.}
\] \[
c_i + \sum_{j=1}^n x_{ji} = z_i f(x_{i1},...,x_{in}; I_{i1},...,I_{im}) \text{ where } i = 1,...,n
\] \[
\sum_{i=1}^n I_{ik} = h_k \text{ where } k = 1,...,m
\]
The constrained optimisation problem can therefore be written as,
\[
\mathcal{L} = u(c_1,...,c_n) - \sum_i^n \eta_i \left[c_i + \sum_{j=1}^n x_{ji} = z_i f(x_{i1},...,x_{in}; I_{i1},...,I_{im})\right] - \sum_{i=1}^m \omega_j \left[\sum_{i=1}^n I_{ik} - h_k\right]
\]
How does GDP change when good \(i\) has a higher productivity?
Using the envelope theorem, in the neighbourhood of the efficient allocation, we can say that \(\frac{dY}{d z_i} = \frac{\delta\mathcal{L}}{\delta z_i}\):
\[
\frac{\delta\mathcal{L}}{\delta z_i} = \eta_i f(x_{i1},...,x_{in};I_{i1},..., I_{im}) = \frac{\eta_iy_i}{z_i}
\]
To express this as an elasticity, in percentage terms,
\[
\frac{d \log Y}{d\log z_i} = \frac{d Y}{d z_i}\frac{z_i}{Y} = \frac{\eta_i y_i}{z_i} \frac{z_i}{Y} = \frac{\eta_i y_i}{Y}
\]
What is the first order condition for the consumption of good \(i\)?
\[
\left.\frac{\delta \mathcal{L}}{\delta c_i}\right|_{c_i^*} = \frac{\delta u}{\delta c_i} - \eta_i = 0
\] \[
\frac{\delta u}{\delta c_i} = \eta_i
\]
How can we use the household problem to get at the marginal utility of good \(i\)?
As the welfare theorems hold, the household problem is the same as the social planner’s problem.
\[
Y = \max_{c_i, I_{ik}, x_{ij}} u(c_1, ... , c_n) \text{ s.t. }\sum_{j=1}^n p_ic_i = \sum_{k=1}^m w_k h_k
\]

What is the first order condition from the decentralised equilibrium problem?
Langrangian:
\[
  \mathcal{L} = u(c_1,...,c_n) - \phi \left(\sum_{j=1}^n p_ic_i - \sum_{k=1}^m w_k h_k \right)
  \]
FOC:
\[
  \left .\frac{\delta \mathcal{L}}{\delta c_i}\right|_{c_i^*} = \frac{\delta u}{\delta c_i} - \phi p_i = 0
  \] \[
  \frac{\delta u}{\delta c_i} = \phi p_i = \eta_i
  \]







Note



This means we can rewrite \(\frac{d \log Y}{d\log z_i} = \frac{\eta_i y_i}{Y}\) as \(\frac{\phi p_i y_i}{Y}\).


How can we use Euler’s homogeneous function theorem to relate GDP to utility?
Euler’s homogeneous function theorem for 1st degree homogeneity says that,
\[
\sum_{j \in h} f_j'(h) \times j = f(h)
\]
where \(h\) is a full set of variables, \(f_j'(h)\) is the partial derivative of \(f\) with respect to \(h\).

Example
\[
  y = k^\alpha l^{1-\alpha}
  \] \[
  \begin{split}
  &\text{(1): }y_k' = \alpha k^{\alpha - 1}l^{1-\alpha},\\&\text{(2): } y'_l = (1-\alpha)k^\alpha l^{-\alpha}
  \end{split}
  \] \[
  k y_k' + ly_l' = y\alpha + y(1-\alpha) = y
  \]

In our case, \(Y = u(c_1,...,c_n) = \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{\delta u}{\delta c_i}c_i \implies Y = \phi \sum_{i=1}^n p_i c_i = \phi \text{GDP}\).
Combining these together gives,
\[
\frac{d \log Y}{d \log z_i} = \frac{\phi p_iy_i}{\phi \text{GDP}} = \frac{p_i y_i}{\text{GDP}}
\]






Hulten’s theorem



All you need to know to determine the effect of shocks to \(i\) is their Domar weight or share of sales in GDP.

The microeconomic details of the production structure are irrelevant.
Intuitively, this is because sales capture both consumption and use as an intermediate input.
